item.title: Lincoln Home National Historic Site Boundary Modification Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on National Parks, Forests, and Public Lands.

item.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. (text: CR S3425-3426)

item.name: Presidents and presidential powers, Vice Presidents

summary.text:
Lincoln Home National Historic Site Boundary Modification Act

This bill modifies the boundary of the Lincoln Home National Historic Site in Illinois as generally depicted on the map titled Proposed Boundary Expansion of the Lincoln Home National Historic Site and dated February 26, 2021.

To improve accessibility, the Department of the Interior shall modify the following areas located within the boundary of the historic site to provide universal design and accessibility by raising the height of the street to match the height of the sidewalk with no sloped surfaces:

  • the intersection at 8th Street and Jackson Street, and
  • the area in front of the home of Abraham Lincoln.

bill.title: Lincoln Home National Historic Site Boundary Modification Act

item.title: Lincoln Home National Historic Site Boundary Modification Act
A bill to modify the boundary of the Lincoln Home National Historic Site in the State of Illinois.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
